summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, outlining the government's plan to obtain and review investigative files from the prior Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (2005-2010) for potential disclosure in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It details the legal framework for disclosure obligations and lists six specific sources of Florida investigation materials the government intends to review. This is a government court filing from October 7, 2020, addressed to Judge Alison J. Nathan. It details the prosecution's planned approach to gathering and reviewing materials from prior investigations (specifically the USAO-SDFL Florida investigation and USAO-SDGA's involvement in CVRA civil litigation) for potential disclosure obligations (Giglio/3500 material) in the Ghislaine Maxwell prosecution. The government asserts these other offices are not part of the current prosecution team but outlines extensive review efforts.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell; recipient of this government letter outlining discovery review plans.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)) for which this discovery plan is being formulated.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the prior Florida Investigation (2005-2010) for sexual abuse of minors; his case files are being sought for review in the Maxwell prosecution.

persons.name: Attorney-1
persons.context: The primary line Assistant U.S. Attorney who worked on the Florida Investigation in the Southern District of Florida; their emails were gathered by the DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting U.S. Attorney who submitted this filing on behalf of the government.

connections.description: Maxwell is being prosecuted for charges arising from an investigation into Epstein's sexual abuse of minors, indicating an alleged conspiratorial relationship.
Attorney-1 was the primary line prosecutor for the federal investigation and prosecution of Epstein in Florida.
Attorney-1 was the primary line assistant on the prior Florida investigation involving Epstein, which is related to the conduct now charged against Maxwell.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is submitting this legal filing to Judge Nathan regarding disclosure obligations in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Initial Conference in Maxwell Case
events.description: Court asked the Government about its plan to ensure timely review of files from other agencies for potential disclosures.

events.title: Start of Florida Investigation
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department opened its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sexual abuse of minors.

events.title: Federal Florida Investigation
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida and the FBI's Palm Beach office conducted a federal investigation into Epstein.

events.title: PBSA File Received
events.description: The Palm Beach State's Attorney's Office provided its entire case file (4,421 pages, audio/video files) to the SDNY prosecution team.

events.title: USAO-SDFL File Received
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida provided its entire investigative file (approx. 28 boxes) in electronic form to the SDNY prosecution team.

events.title: USAO-SDGA Designated for CVRA Litigation
events.description: Attorneys from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Georgia were designated to represent the U.S. in CVRA civil litigation brought by Epstein victims after the USAO-SDFL was recused.

events.title: Government Files Disclosure Plan
events.description: The government files this detailed plan with the court outlining its approach to reviewing materials from prior investigations for potential disclosure in the Ghislaine Maxwell prosecution.

locations: Southern District of New York (current prosecution jurisdiction)
keyFacts: The prosecution team (SDNY USAO, FBI NY, NYPD) had no involvement in the prior Florida Investigation into Epstein, which concluded about eight years before the Maxwell investigation began.
The government states it has no legal obligation to obtain the Florida files but is doing so 'above and beyond' its disclosure obligations.
The government has already obtained and is reviewing the full FBI Florida Office case file, which it believes contains 'substantially all' prior witness statements from the Florida Investigation.
Six potential sources of Florida Investigation material are identified: PBPD, PBSA, FBI Florida Office, USAO-SDFL, DOJ OPR emails, and the 'Kellen' obstruction case files.

The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) gathered emails from USAO-SDFL attorneys, including a primary prosecutor ('Attorney-1'), as part of an investigation into the resolution of the Florida case.

The government plans to electronically search emails of 'Attorney-1', the primary prosecutor from the prior Florida investigation, for names of the defendant (Maxwell), victims, and witnesses to find any non-duplicative Giglio or 3500 material.
The government asserts there is not a substantial number of overlapping victims or witnesses between the prior Florida investigation and the current Maxwell prosecution in New York.

The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Georgia (USAO-SDGA) was involved in CVRA civil litigation on behalf of the U.S. after the Florida office was recused; the government will contact them to ask about any communications with witnesses relevant to the Maxwell prosecution.

The government maintains that none of the other offices or agencies (USAO-SDFL, USAO-SDGA) are part of the 'Prosecution Team' for the current Maxwell case, as they did not participate in witness interviews, strategy, charging decisions, or grand jury presentations.
